text: And the white glow becomes blue sky, and we FIND the tip church steeple reaching to heaven. And as we WIDEN we see that it’s attached to a small, white clapboard church somewhere in the suburbs of a big city. A SIGN out front tells us where we are and the late-model cars parked out front tell us when: the early 1990s. And as the CAMERA continues its move, we settle on a WHITE ROSE in the f.g.

Which becomes an entire BOUQUET of WHITE ROSES. And then CAMERA will carry us to soft CLOSE UPS of a wedding cerem in progress: SUNLIGHT streaming in an stained glass window and pointin an ornate cross on a church wall. The lapel of a tuxedo jacket, adorned with a tie made of colorful African fabric. The beautiful train of a wedding gown surrounded by white rose petals on the red carpet. Two black hands, one soft and feminine, and one masculine athletic lighting a unity candle. An open Bible in a strong BLACK MINISTER’S hands. A handkerchief wiping tears from old black eyes in the audience. A glistening diamond ring is slipped by the masculine han onto a soft, feminine finger. Two pairs of moist lips meet in a passionate kiss. As the SONG ENDS, we’1ll WIDEN from the kiss to reveal handsome, sturdily-built, tuxedoed DAVE JOHNSON, probably embracing his gorgeous, not-much-younger bride, CLARICE C JOHNSON. And as they hold their kiss for what seems like long, we see that we are in a nicely appointed sanctuary filled with happy, mostly black WEDDING GUESTS. (CONTINUED )
The Fade hairstyles on the men and Anita Baker bobs on th women date us to the early 1990s.
They are all presided over by larger-than-life BISHOP WIL dressed in ministerial robes with colorful Afrocentric accents. He taps Dave on the shoulder.

How about saving some for the honeymoon, brother? Dave and Clarice break their clutch, slightly embarrassed and the audience erupts in LAUGHTER and a few HOOTS and HOLLAS from some of the men, including handsome, young Be Man BROCK HOUSEMAN, the lone Caucasian member of the wedd party. And he’s the got an all-business-up-front-party-in back mullett going for him, which puts him right out of college, and not yet quite legit. Dave and Clarice now turn to face the Bishop. He smiles a them broadly and holds up his Bible again.

Dave... Clarice, before I present you as husband and wife, there’s one last lesson I want to leave with you as you begin your life together. A wise king named Solomon once said this: (reading from Bible) “It is better to have a partner than go through life alone. Share the work, share the wealth, for if one falls down, the other is there to pick him up. But pity the man who falls and has no one by his side. And in bed, two can warm each other at night. But one alone, shivers all night long. By yourself, you are unprotected. But with a partner you can face the worst the world has to offer. But even better is a cord of three strands because it is not easily broken.” (beat, closing his Bible) My brother, my sister... I’1l be honest with you. Life is gonna do its best to beat you up. And it’s hard to keep the good in a good marriage when bad things happen. (CONTINUED)
The Bishop then retrieves a gold-colored, braided cord, a places one end around Dave’s shoulders and then drapes th other end around Clarice’s shoulders.

This is a three-stranded cord. The two of you represent the first two strands, but God represent the third. And as long as you stay close to God and His family, I promise your marriage will be a three-stranded cord that nothing in this world can break. And as Dave and Clarice nod that they understand the admonition, we’ll FIND Clarice’s 50-something, very stron willed mother, MARY CLARK, or MAMA as we will come to kno her, sitting all by herself in the front row. And she’s watching these proceedings with uncertain, skeptical eyes And we'll PRELAP the smooth sounds of BLACK wedding DJ an the end of some R & B number like “AIN’T NO WAY.”
All right, give it up for sister Aretha.

The place has been decorated for a wedding reception. Tables, linens, disco ball and rotund DJ with his sound system set up in front of a dance floor packed with guest including Bishop Wilkes, who is mixing it up with his WIF
Step aside, peeps. DJ Supersize comin’ at you now with a special dance request. The wedding guests begin clearing the dance floor.
Time for the bride’s own mama, Mrs. Mary Clark, to step on the floor with her new son-in-law. Mama smiles coyly as she takes to the floor. (CONTINUED)
(suggestively) Lord have mercy, Mrs. Clark. Could you be my mama... ‘cuz I love the way you cookin’ tonight. Which draws HOOTS and HOWLS from across the hall. She wav him off with mock humility.
At the edge of the crowd, Dave is standing with his new b and his best man Brock, with whom he trades a hesitant lo
Oh, damn.
(rolling her eyes) Please. She ain’t gonna bite you. Dave starts moving sheepishly out onto the floor. Brock calls after him and doing his best Vanilla Ice impression
I got your back, dawg. Clarice elbows Brock in the ribs as Dave joins Mama to th APPLAUSE of the wedding guests.

This one goes out to all you mamas. From my man, Babyface. Mama plasters on a smile and puts her arms around Dave's neck. He puts his hands appropriately around her waist, a the DJ throws the switch on a tune like “SONG FOR MY MAMA And they dance together for a long moment as Clarice and of her bridesmaids watch, their emotions brimming over th beautiful scene.
Mama pulls in close and begins to talk in hushed tones to Dave, her manufactured smile never leaving her face.
Welcome to the family, baby.
Thank you, Mrs. Clark. (CONTINUED)
(admonishingly) Boy, I know you did not just call me “Mrs. Clark.” I expect you to call me “Mama.” Just like I expect you and my Reesie at my house every week for Sunday dinner.
(taken aback) Yes, ma’am.

Just like I expect you to learn how to hold a job, keep food on the table, and stay away from all them ghetto-pass-carryin’, crack-dealin’ street hustlers you used to run with. I don’t care if you did graduate from college, I will not see my baby girl have anything less than the life she deserves.
No, ma’am.

And one more thing. You a man, so you probably can’t help yourself, but if I ever catch you puttin’ your eyes on some little Miss Thang who ain’t my daughter, I will personally come over there like Jesus and pluck them out. Are you feelin’ me? A shell-shocked Dave looks at her for a long moment. Ther a lot he would like to say, but he thinks better of it.
I feel you. Mama's smile says that’s exactly how she wants it to be. Just then, Clarice taps her mother on the shoulder.
My turn, Mama.
Yes, it is, baby. (patting Dave on cheek) This boy and me gonna get along just fine. (CONTINUED)

And with that, Mama moves off into the crowd. As Clarice Dave begin to dance, the DJ transitions us into Lionel Richie’s “THREE TIMES A LADY.” Clarice notices that Dave a little shaken by his encounter with Mama.
I know Mama can come on a little strong.
More like a Mack truck.
She just wants the best for me.
I know.
(smiling seductively) But she ain’t comin’ where we goin’ tonight. Which quickly snaps Dave out of his funk.
Did I mention how good you look in that dress?
Yes. But do you know how good I’m gonna look out of it?

(eyes heaven gratefully) Thank you, Jesus. And as they share an expectation of intimacy that only a groom and bride can share, Clarice will pull Dave into a kiss. And suddenly, it will be as if they are all alone i the world, with space and time SPINNING AROUND THEM. And will begin to hear Dave’s REMEMBERING VOICE as the song continues to play.

When I was growing up on my Granny’s knee, we were poor as church mice. Scratch that. The church mice were the rich ones. We were the church rats. But it didn’t matter because Granny raised me to know right from wrong. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

And before she passed on, God rest her soul, she worked her fingers to the bone makin’ sure I could get out the hood, makin’ sure I could be a college boy. And she was the only woman I ever worshipped until the day I met a young lady in college who could make Halle Berry want to eat her heart out.

Clarice was the most beautiful woman I had ever laid eyes on. And together we were goin’ places in this world. Someday, she was gonna be the Donald Trump of Dallas, and I was gonna coach Longhorn basketball. This was a lady a brother would go to war for. A lady a man could pledge to be faithful to, and yes, to keep his eyes from getting plucked out for. C) CLARICE SHOWING HER ENGAGEMENT RING TO HER GAL-PALS.

text: As Bishop Wilkes, my childhood pastor, had said... she was a woman to have and to hold, and to cherish until you breathe your last.
WITH THE “JUST MARRIED” HANGING OFF THE BACK END.
And that’s exactly what I did. On our wedding night, it was me, Clarice and a little bit of heaven. And we didn’t come up for air for two days. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

With all your hopes and plans and dreams right out in front of you like that, the honeymoon can last forever. G) DAVE AND CLARICE POSING IN FRONT A “JUST SOLD” REAL ES SIGN IN FRONT OF A SMALL BUNGALOW -- THEIR FIRST HOME.
MAMA IN HER HOUSE. AND WE’LL PUSH IN ON DAVE’S FORCED SMI

INT. DAVE’S PANEL VAN - DAY - TRAVELING (PRESENT DAY) We’re still CLOSE ON Dave, only now he looks a dozen year older in a work shirt that marks him as working class. A more worry lines around the eyes. A few gray hairs dustin his temples. And somehow “THREE TIMES A LADY” never quit playing. In fact we’re now hearing it on the car radio. B as Dave drives along, he is deep in thought. On the other side of the boulevard, a Police cruiser zoom past, its SIREN WAILING, pulling Dave out of his thoughts He inadvertently flips the radio dial to a NEWSTALK stati
But just like the Bishop said, life has a way of knocking the hell out of you. We’1ll PULL OUTSIDE the van far enough to read the sign o side of his truck. “ALL-PRO JANITORIAL & CARPET CLEANING.

Dave’s van pulls into the driveway of a nice, upper middl class home in a neighborhood full of similar homes. (This not the starter home we saw them buy, but a step up into suburbs). A recent model Cadillac V-Series is already sitting in the driveway, with one of those magnetic signs plastered on the door: “HASTINGS PROPERTIES & REAL ESTATE

Clarice, still looking as girlishly trim and put-together she did on her wedding day, is noshing on a salad at a si bar in the well-appointed kitchen while reading House Beautiful magazine. She’s dressed smartly in a sexy blous and skirt as Dave enters. He brightens when he sees her. (CONTINUED)
Damn, girl. All those curves and me with no brakes.
Hey, baby. Dave crosses over, moves in for a kiss. But she turns her cheek to him.
Sorry. I just touched up my face. Dave shrugs it off. Gives her a peck on the cheek.
How was your day? Dave opens the fridge, and pops the top on a bottle of be
I had to do the bank building myself because two of my boys called in sick. I tell you, Reesie, why I let you talk me into starting my own business I’m still trying to figure out.

(slightly irritated) Baby, we been over all this. Coaching JV football wasn’t puttin’ us in this zip code. You just got to do a better job of hiring the right people. Dave has heard this lecture before and Clarice can see he tired of it. She softens her approach.
Besides, you think I want my big, strong chocolate kiss waxin’ floors for a livin’? I want you in the executive suite where you deserve to be. Dave gives her a reluctant smile. The sweets worked.
I know, Boo. He comes around behind her. Starts massaging her shoulder (CONTINUED)
Whaddya say we forget all that nonsense tonight and get us little quality time? She melts a little at his touch, but remembers her job.
Oh, that sounds so good. But I got to show houses tonight.
What about tomorrow?
That’s no good either. It’s my real estate board dinner. You promised to sit with Mama while I sit up at the main table, remember?
(blanching at reminder) Oh, shit, that’s right.
(looks at him askance) I know I did not hear you cussin’ in this house about Mama. Clarice puts on her colorful real-estate blazer.
I tell you what. If you show Mama a nice time, somebody gonna get his freak on Saturday night. She nibbles on his ear a little. Dave’s jelly. Clarice knows it. Right where she wants him.
I‘1l even throw in one of those lacy numbers that gets you all weak in the knees. Dave looks her in the eye, hopefully.
Maybe we could also... you know... talk about the future.
Let’s not go there, baby. You know I’m not ready for that. (CONTINUED)
She gives him another peck on the cheek and exits. His countenance falls as he watches her go.

As we SWOOP DOWN over Dallas after dark, it’s all glass a prisms of light, especially in the priciest piece of real estate in town, the 40-story Trinity View condo building. INT. BROCK HOUSEMAN’S DOWNTOWN CONDO - NIGHT We’re CLOSE ON the timer of fancy blender whose jar conta water and some kind of protein powder. The timer hits 6:1 p.m. and the machine suddenly whirs to life, blending up contents into some kind of green health drink. And we'll WIDEN to see that we are in a gourmet kitchen i very upscale bachelor condo with skyrise views on three sides. The place looks like a Bang & Olufsen store threw -- leather furniture, modern art, giant plasma screen TV the wall and all the digital trappings. At that moment, the front door opens and Brock Houseman enters, looking as fit and handsome as ever, his college- mullett replaced with close-cropped George Clooney hair. throws off his expensive suit coat and loosens a tie as h crosses over to his telephone on the kitchen counter. He punches in a phone number, then his voice-mail code, a puts the phone to his ear as he pours his smoothie into a glass and begins chugging as he listens.
Four new messages... He punches a key to listen.
(flirty and sexy) Hey, Cowboy, it’s Vickie. It’s been too long since the last time we hooked up. I got the hot tub heating up in case you’re lonely tonight. Brock gulps weakly and steels his courage.
Stay strong, bro. (CONTINUED)
He pushes a key and we hear the ERASE tone. Then the next message begins to play.

Hi, sweetie pie, this is Mom. Are you getting my messages? Something must be wrong with your system. Anyway, my friend Sophie has this really lovely niece who sings in the church choir and you won’t believe what she does for a living -- she’s a professional bowler. Isn’t that fun? Anyway, I thought maybe I could have the two of you over for dinner Friday and -- Brock sighs and punches to ERASE the message.
Sorry, Mom, I’m having my finger nails ripped out that night. And then yet one more feminine voice comes on the line.

Hi, Brock... this is Partygirl 229 Remember me from Singles Chat-dot- com? I got your number from Surferdude 102 who it got it froma friend of his who knows how to track people down. I was thinking we could meet for drinks and -- Brock punches the ERASE button, looks at the phone horrif
Okay, now I’m officially scared. Finally a voice he wants to hear comes on the line.
Yo, B, it’s Dave. Reesie’s working tonight. If your lawyer ass ain't too busy, what do you say we get our hoops on? Holler back at me. Brock smiles, relieved, as he hangs up the phone.
(like a black guy) Now that’s what I’m talking about.

We’re HIGH and WIDE on an imposing downtown hospital with heavy Catholic influence on the facade. As we PUSH IN, we FIND an ambulance parked at the emergency entrance. And j at that moment, its SIRENS and LIGHTS come on and it peel away from the hospital on its way to only God knows where

We’re CLOSE ON a bare leg with a fresh surgical scar at t knee joint engaged in a knee-extension exercise, and WIDE see an OLDER MALE PATIENT painfully raising his leg as a pretty, perky physical therapist in her early 30s coaches through it. She is not a stone fox, but Meg Ryan sexy -- despite the perspiration on her brow and the fatigue of a long shift in a busy PT clinic
Just a few more, Jerry. Before you know it, you’ll have that new bionic knee out on the dance floor.
It hurts like hell. (mischievous smile) Maybe you could kiss it and make it better.
(rolls eyes, teasingly) Behave yourself. She calls to a passing PT ASSISTANT.

Electrical stim, then ice for Mister Hound Dog here. (smiling at Jerry) On second thought, no stimulation. He’s already had enough of that. Julie trades another smile and a wink with Leonard as the Assistant takes over for her.
TRACK Julie over to the bullpen where she hands Jerry’s c to a middle-aged, humorless-looking OFFICE SUPERVISOR.
Okay, Nick, who’s my next victim? (CONTINUED)
The supervisor just stares at her -- flatly.
It was a joke. That would be where I say something funny and you make this little noise called a laugh.
We got a memo from corporate.
What'd it say? They taking away our vending machine? No more Little Debbies at snack break? He hands her the memo. Her smile fades as she reads it.
Part time? Are you kidding me? The patient load is higher than it’s ever been.
Costs are up. We're going to have to figure out a way to see same number of clients in half the time.
Cheap-frigging-HMO. What’s next -- instead of Viagra, a Popsicle stick and duct tape?
I’m sorry, Julie. I don’t know what to tell you.
I’m raising a 12-year-old son. How do I replace this income?
Look, you’re my best therapist. I’1l try to throw some freelance work your way.
Don’t bother. I’11 just sell one of my organs. Who needs two kidneys anyway? She throws up her hands in frustration and crosses out.

A shiny black BMW with high performance tires pulls into and Clarice’s driveway and HONKS its horn. From inside, s clean-enough-for-radio RAP SONG from a high-end sound sys INT. BROCK’S BMW - NIGHT - MOMENT LATER Brock, now dressed in ratty gym clothes, is sitting in th car, RAPPING along with the song throbbing on the Blaupun when the passenger door opens and Dave slides in. He’s al wearing sweats, and carrying a basketball. Brock offers h fist to Dave for a knuckle-bump.
(loudly over Rap song) What up, D... how you doin’? Dave can hardly hear him over the radio.
Hey, Grandmaster Flash, you wanna chill the jams before one of my white neighbors has a heart attack.

Sorry, bro. My bad. Brock turns down the volume. Dave chuckles as Brock backs car out of the driveway. This sort of black/white reparte is obviously something that’s part of their friendship. INT. BROCK’S BMW - TRAVELING - NIGHT - A MOMENT LATER They have now left Dave’s neighborhood and are proceeding toward downtown, the skyline closing in out the window.
Glad you called me tonight, man.
Saved from another lonely night in that million-dollar penthouse, huh?
It’s two million, but who’s counting? Besides, I could be hitting it with any number of ladies if I wanted to. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

I’m just taking a little break right now to get my head straight, you know what I’m saying? Long as I got my “Good Times” reruns, it’s all good. Dave doesn’t know whether to laugh... or be weirded out.
Tell me you do not watch “Good Times.”
I love that show. It reminds me of when I was just a shorty living in the ghet-to.
Please. A white trash trailer park ain’t no ghetto.
(winking at Dave) I know, but I’m just trying to keep it real for my main homey, ya'll.
(chuckling) Has anybody ever told you that you are one strange Caucasian?

(dropping black patois) This coming from a black guy who lives in the whitest neighborhood in the city. Brock smiles, offers his palm. Dave has to give him some skin on that one. These guys have a real bond.
A classy real estate office building with lovely landscap and a sign matching the magnetic placard on Clarice’s Cadillac, which is just now pulling into a parking spot.
When Clarice enters, she is instantly waylaid by MICHELLE her sassy, brassy, late-20s black assistant who has opini on every subject and is not shy about sharing them. (CONTINUED)
Okay, girlfriend, here’s the four- one-one. She hands Clarice a file folder and points through a wind into her office where an upscale, professional-looking bl couple, THE REIDS, are waiting.
Mr. Superior Court Judge in there is married to Miz chi chi art dealer and they are looking to get up into a new zip code.
Where do they want to look?
Hillwood.
That's a nice zip code.
Go get the money, sister girl. We about to get paid. Clarice gets a wry smile. And she crosses into her office
Mr. and Mrs. Reid, I’m Clarice Johnson. So nice to meet you. And we begin HEARING some jam like 50 Cent’s “PLACES TO G

As it SLAMS THROUGH THE NET, and then WIDEN to see we’re an inner-city gymnasium in the middle of a shirts-and-ski pick-up basketball game. Dave comes down hard, having just slammed-dunked the ball over a tatted-up, street-looking black dude in his 30s we come to know as DARNELL GOODEN. Dave thumps his bare, sweaty, chiseled chest proudly and exchanges high-fives w bare-chested Brock and then a couple of his other African American TEAMMATES. Darnell is fuming.
That was charging, dawg! (CONTINUED)

Gimme the lane if you don’t want my foot in your hind parts, homey. (motions for the ball) Ball! Darnell casts an angry look at Dave. One of the other players chunks the ball to Dave who takes it to the basel Dave takes the ball in, tossing it to one of his teammate really BIG DUDE with a perpetual smile, and we’ll TRACK h as he begins dribbling the ball down court as Darnell and team get back on defense. And for a long time, it’s all passes and shiny bodies slamming into one another. And th Dave gets the ball back and sees Brock in the open in thr point territory. And the action we’ll STROBE into:

A) Dave fires a chest past to Brock. B) Darnell sees what’s happening and moves into action. C) As Brock goes up for his shot, a black fist flies INTO FRAME and connects with his face -- hard. D) Brock slams to the floor and the ball goes rolling out bounds, and we'll be overtaken by REAL TIME once again. Brock jumps to his feet, blood gushing from his nose, and immediately charges Darnell. And soon they are a whirling dervish of flying kicks and punches, and Dave and some of other players immediately rush in to break it up.
Yo, knock it off! Break it up! Finally Dave and a teammate are able to pry them apart an Brock and Darnell both come out of the tussle spitting ma
(glaring at Darnell) What the hell was that, man?
(thrusts a finger at Dave) Nigger wanted street rules.
You better check yourself, brother. You ain’t in the prison yard no more! (CONTINUED)
Rage fills Darnell’s eyes and he suddenly charges Dave, pinning him to the wall before Brock and the others can p them apart. Dave is quaking with frustration, disbelief.
What is your problem, fool?

You, college boy, strollin’ up in here with your suburb-livin,’ white ass-kissin’ nose in the air... (pointing at Brock) --. bringin’ this lil’ Jimmy Crack Corn which you. Dave flares at this and trades an uncomfortable look with Brock, but thinks better of fanning the flames.
Come on, brother, we homeys from way back. Why you got to sweat me like that?

You used to be good people when you wasn’t too good for the hood. But forget this shit! I ain’t rollin’ with no Uncle Tom! Darnell picks up the ball and fires it to the Big Dude, w no longer has a smile. Darnell starts to walk off. Brock tries one last appeal.
Let’s just finish the game, Darnell. No harm, no foul.
(turning back, glaring) Shut up, punk! Go back to Starbucks! With that, Darnell is out of there, leaving nothing but frustrated looks all around, especially from Dave and Bro
We’re in the beautiful, elegantly appointed foyer of a suburban mini-mansions. Clarice enters with The Reids fro the living room and we TRACK them as they move through. (CONTINUED)
Mrs. Reid 20.
I assume the sellers are looking for full price?
We can try, but I doubt they’1l come down from one-point-seven.
Nor should they. I love the balance and harmony of this place. It has perfect Feng Shui.
Right down to the warm earth tones and east-facing front door.
I’m glad we have the same tastes.
(smiles, gratified) Me, too.
If you ask me, it all sounds like mumbo-jumbo. rolls her eyes and shares a smile with Clarice.
My husband said just about the same thing when we were picking out our home. I think the term he used was... “load of bull.”
(chuckling) Good man. What line of work he in? Catching Clarice off guard. She has to think how to answe Mrs. Reid
Oh, he... uh... runs his own building management firm.
Tell him I like the way he thinks.
(averting his eyes) I will. grabs her by the elbow and starts up the stairs. (CONTINUED)
Come on, Clarice. I wanna see how my chi flows in the master bedroom. And the two of them head upstairs, Clarcie’s confident sm returning. And we’ll PRELAP the sound of a coach’s WHISTL
The lean, young body belongs to 12-year-old BRYSON SAWYER he knifes into the water.
And we now know we are watching a 50-meter freestyle race between several adolescent boys in an Olympic-size pool i outdoor swim stadium with bleachers and stadium lights lighting up the night sky.

Bryson hits the opposite wall a half-length behind the leader, but coming out of his flip turn, he turns on the afterburners and easily zooms into the lead. He hits the wall in first place, a length ahead of the next best swim And a mother’s shrill voice pierces the air.
Whoo-hoo! Bryson! You-da-man!

As Bryson climbs out of the pool, we can see he’s a good- looking kid with an innocent face. He looks up to see his mother, Julie Sawyer, rushing over with a towel. He looks over at some of the other teenage swimmers, whose mothers pulling similar stunts. They all look completely humiliat
Way to go, Sweetheart! You rock!
Mom, stop. It’s embarrassing you slobbering all over me like this.
Oh, excuse me for gettin’ a little worked up because my twelve-year- old son just cleaned the clocks of a pool full of high school freshmen. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
Buster, you won’t ever be too big for your speedos for me to love on you. Got it?
(sighs, impatient) Fine. Julie grabs his chin and forces him to look her in the ey
And why is that?
Can we do this later?
Nope. Give it to me. He rolls his eyes, then quietly gives her the response sh wants -- a routine they clearly have been through many ti
Because it’s just you and me, Mom. Her eyes glisten with love.
That’s right, baby. Just you and me against the world. Their moment is interrupted by COACH SPINELLO, a thick, g looking man in his late-twenties.
Hey, Bryson, nice heat. Got any idea what your time was?
I don’t know. Around twenty-three seconds?
Try twenty-one and nine-tenths.
Whoa.
You’re dang-right-whoa. That’s a high school varsity time, bro. Bryson looks at his mother, amazed. She beams. (CONTINUED)
I’m not saying anything, Coach. I’m supposed to keep my trap shut.
(smiles, then) So how do you feel about adding the relay on Saturday? I want you to swim the free-style leg with the fourteen-year-olds.
(as in “totally cool”) That would be totally ridiculous.
I’ll take that as a “yes.” (turns to go, then remembers something) Oh, Mrs. Sawyer... ?
Miss Sawyer.
Sorry. The team mom asked me to remind you we still need your check for the new club warm-up suits.
I’m sorry. Completely slipped my mind. I’11 bring one Saturday.
Sounds great. The coach bumps knuckles with Bryson and crosses off. Bry gives Julie a probing look. But she switches gears on him
You know what I’m in the mood for? Burger Cabana. But as she busies herself with packing up his stuff, he k his eye on her. That check thing bothers him.

INT. BROCK’S BMW - TRAVELING - NIGHT They guys are chillin’ with Gatorade and the windows down they drive back from the Y in Brock’s sweet ride. But Dav is clearly still fuming about his run-in on the court. (CONTINUED)
I’ve known Darnell from knee-high to a Pontiac. I don’t know why he has to do me like that. Brock looks at Dave and smiles knowingly. They’ve had thi conversation before.
Seems pretty simple to me. You stole his college scholarship and he’s still ticked off about it.
I didn’t steal nothing from nobody. The brother got caught dealin’ crack and lost his scholarship. I earned mine fair and square.
Still, I know how he feels... being the better athlete and all. Dave gives him a look of disbelief.
Better athlete, my ass. Now you the one smoking crack. Brock smiles. Dave knows he’s been had.
Somehow it all got messed up. Two shorties knockin’ around the hood, dreamin’ about being Michael Jordan. One ends up a broke-ass bail-jumper. The other one ends up gettin’ a piece of the pie.
Victim of his circumstances.

Shit, that ain’t circumstances, that’s choices. Circumstances is tidal waves and hurricanes. Choices is “Should I or shouldn’t I sling this crack?” (winking at Brock) “Should I or shouldn’t I punch this white Superstar in the nose?” (CONTINUED)

No, circumstances is having no father around to teach you how not to smoke crack because the government forgot to fix the levies and a hurricane just flooded your house. You got to have boots to have bootstraps, brother.
Look at you, all white and liberal and trippin’ like you a member of the Rainbow Coalition. Brock has to laugh about this.

I guess you’re right. Life isn’t fair. Otherwise, some butt-ugly sucker like you doesn’t end up with a fine lady like Clarice while a rich, handsome dude like me is till trollin’ singles bars. Dave gets his chuckle on.
